verse: Paul said, “[Men,] Brothers and fathers, listen to my defense to you.”
When they heard him ·speaking [addressing them in] the Hebrew [or Aramaic; 21:40] language, they became ·very [even more] quiet. Paul said,

“I am a Jew, born in Tarsus [9:11] in the ·country [province] of Cilicia [6:9], but I ·grew up [was brought up; or was educated] in this city [Jerusalem]. I was ·a student of [instructed at the feet of; idiom indicating the role of a disciple] Gamaliel [a famous teacher of the Pharisees; 5:34], who ·carefully [or strictly] taught me everything about the law of our ·ancestors [forefathers; fathers]. I was ·very serious about serving [zealous/passionate for] God, just as are all of you here today.

I persecuted the people who followed ·the Way of Jesus [this Way; another name for the Christian movement; 9:2; 18:25; 19:23], ·and some of them were even killed [up to the point of death; 7:60]. I ·arrested [bound] men and women and put them in jail.

The high priest and the whole council of elders can ·tell you this is true [testify about me]. They gave me letters to the brothers [their fellow Jewish leaders] in Damascus. So I was going there to ·arrest [bind] these people and bring them back to Jerusalem to be punished.
“About noon when I came near Damascus, a bright light from heaven suddenly ·flashed [shone] all around me.
I fell to the ground and heard a voice saying, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?’
I asked, ‘Who are you, Lord?’ ·The voice [He] said, ‘I am Jesus ·of Nazareth [or the Nazarene] whom you are persecuting.’
Those who were with me did not ·understand [or hear; the word can mean either “hear” or “understand,” but 9:7 suggests the latter] the voice [that was speaking to me], but they saw the light.
I said, ‘What shall I do, Lord?’ The Lord answered, ‘Get up and go to Damascus. There you will be told about all the things ·I have planned [or assigned; appointed] for you to do.’
I could not see, because ·the bright light had made me blind [of the glory/brilliance of that light]. So ·my companions [those with me] led me [by the hand] into Damascus.

“There a man named Ananias came to me. He was a ·religious [devout; God-fearing] man; ·he obeyed the law of Moses […according to the law], and all the Jews who lived there ·respected [spoke well of] him.
He [came to me and] stood by me and said, ‘Brother Saul, ·see again [look up; an idiom for regaining sight]!’ ·Immediately [At that hour] I ·was able to see [looked up at] him.

He said, ‘The God of our ·ancestors [forefathers; fathers] ·chose [appointed] you long ago to know his ·plan [will; purpose], to see the Righteous One [Jesus], and to hear ·words [a divine message; a voice] from ·him [his mouth].
You will be his witness to all people, telling them about what you have seen and heard.
Now, ·why wait any longer [what are you waiting for]? Get up, be baptized, and wash your sins away, ·trusting in him to save you [calling on his name].’
“Later, when I returned to Jerusalem, I was praying in the Temple, and I ·saw a vision [or fell into a trance].
I saw ·the Lord [him] saying to me, ‘Hurry! Leave Jerusalem ·now [or quickly]! The people here will not accept ·the truth [your testimony/witness] about me.’
But I said, ‘Lord, they [themselves; very well] know that in every synagogue I put ·the believers [those who believe in you] in jail and beat them.

They also know I was there when Stephen, your ·witness [or martyr], ·was killed [had his blood shed]. I [myself; indeed] stood there agreeing and ·holding [guarding; keeping] the coats of those who were killing him!’
But the Lord said to me, ‘·Leave now [Go!]. I will send you far away to the ·other nations [Gentiles].’”

·The crowd [They] listened to ·Paul [him] until he said ·this [this word]. Then they ·began shouting [raised their voice saying], “·Get rid of him [Kill him; Remove this one from the earth]! He doesn’t deserve to live!”
They ·shouted [yelled; screamed], threw off their coats, and threw dust into the air [demonstrations of anger and disgust].

Then the ·commander [tribune] ordered the soldiers to take ·Paul [him] into the ·army building [barracks] and ·beat him [question him by whipping/flogging]. ·He wanted […in order] to make Paul tell why the people were shouting against him like this [flogging was commonly used to gain information].

But as the soldiers were ·tying him up [or stretching him out (on the posts)], preparing to ·beat [whip; flog] him, Paul said to an officer nearby, “Do you have the right to ·beat [whip; flog] a Roman citizen who ·has not been proven guilty [is uncondemned; this was against Roman law]?”

When the ·officer [centurion; 21:32] heard this, he went to the ·commander [tribune] and reported it. The officer said, “·Do you know what you are doing [or What are you about to do]? This man is a Roman citizen.”
The ·commander [tribune] came to ·Paul [him] and said, “Tell me, are you really a Roman citizen?”
The ·commander [tribune] ·said [responded], “I paid a lot of money to become a Roman citizen.”

[Therefore] The men who were preparing to question Paul ·moved away from him [withdrew] immediately. The ·commander [tribune] was frightened because he had already ·tied [bound] ·Paul [him], and Paul was a Roman citizen.

header: Paul Speaks to the Jewish Council

verse: The next day ·the commander [he] ·decided [desired] to learn [with certainty; the true reason] why the Jews were accusing ·Paul [him]. So he ordered the ·leading [chief] priests and the ·council [Sanhedrin; Jewish high court comprised of 70 Jewish leaders; 4:15] to meet. ·The commander [He] ·took Paul’s chains off [released him]. Then he brought Paul out and stood him before their meeting.
